Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on the Meltdown of the Icelandic Economy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will bring together a group of 30 plus international scholars, primarily anthropologist, to produce a thick description of the causes and consequences of the meltdown of the Icelandic economy. The PI hypothesizes that the crisis involved a complex interaction of cultural, economic, political and ideological variables that played off each other from the 1980s surrounding the creation of Individual Transferrable Quotas in the Icelandic fisheries; it is this complex interaction that makes the case a very interesting one for a thick description methodology.

The workshop is scheduled for Fall 2011 at the University Park Campus of Penn State and it is anticipated approximately 30 scholars and graduate students will participate in the 3-day project. The format of the workshop is a standard presentation of scholarly papers with discussion. The attendees will be prepared to discuss specific aspects of the organizing topic and following the workshop the individual papers will be gathered together into a volume, for which the PI Paul Durrenburger and co-organizer, Gisli Paulsson University of Iceland, will produce the introduction and conclusion for the edited volume.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the award was to fund an international and multi-disciplinary examination of the causes and conseuences of the 2008 meltdown of the Icleandic economy. A group of international scholars, mostly Icelandic but also Canadian, Danish, and American gathered at the University of Iowa to discuss each individual contribution...from a banker, an person who studies schools and education, a novelist, a sociologist and several anthropologists. Then each participant returned home and revised his/her contribution. The editors, Gisli Palsson and Paul Durrenberger then edited each paper and when they were done, passed them to a professional editor who comploted the editorial process. When that was finished the book was submitted to the University Press of Colorado for peer review. After minor revisions, the Press published the book and made it available free online in return for a subvention by Polar Programs. 

 

The chief merit of this project was that it was among the first anthropological studies of the effects of neoliberal government policies on a modern economy . While this can be debated in the U.S., it is clear for Iceland that the neoliberal policies resulted in disaster for virtually all citizens. This, in turn, led to a change of government and policies. Naomi Klein has documented the disasterous conseuqnesces of the Chicago School economists in Latin America and Russia. To those examples we can now add Iceland as a precautionary tale.
